thread.title: Former Springsteen bandmate, Robbin Thompson, dies
thread.title_full: Former Springsteen bandmate, Robbin Thompson, dies

author: Alex Napoliello | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Former Springsteen bandmate, Robbin Thompson, dies
text:
Former Springsteen bandmate, Robbin Thompson, dies Springsteen.JPG Robbin Thompson, a former Bruce Springsteen bandmate, died Saturday after a battle with cancer. A scruffy Bruce Springsteen in 1975 is pictured here. (Barbara Pyle | Reel Art Press). Comments 
Robbin Thompson, a former Bruce Springsteen bandmate and co-writer of the official Virginia state song, died early Saturday morning after a battle with cancer. He was 66. 
Thompson's musical career spans more than 40 years, but the Richmond, Va. resident slowed down his touring in recent years. He said on his website that his concert schedule was limited to shows he knows "will be enjoyable." 
In September, Thompson took to his Facebook page to publicly announce his long battle with cancer. 
"I apologize for being out of touch for a while," he wrote. "Many of you know that I've been battling cancer for over 15 years. These days, it's causing a few problems but I'm dealing with it and will be back performing soon. Like real soon. ..." 
Thompson joined Springsteen's pre-E Street band, Steel Mill, as lead singer in 1971. PLUS : EXCLUSIVE: Check out these never-before-seen 'Born To Run' era Springsteen photos 
Springsteen, Vini "Mad Dog" Lopez, Danny Federici and Vinnie Roslin played together in a band called Child. In 1969, Child morphed into Steel Mill, and in 1970, Steven Van Zandt replaced Roslin on bass and Thompson was added as a fifth member. 
Steel Mill never officially released an album; they recorded a three-song demo for legendary concert promoter Bill Graham, but rejected a recording contract that Graham offered. 
In 2004, Lopez reinvented Steel Mill as Steel Mill Retro , but Thompson wasn't included in that rendition of the band. 
Thompson and friend Steve Bassett collaborated in 1978 to create the song, "Sweet Virginia Breeze." It was later adopted as the official "popular" state song in the Old Dominion state. 
Thompson was the vice president and co-founder of In Your Ear Music and Recording Corp. He has shared the stage with music legends such as Bob Dylan, Bonnie Raitt, Crosby, Stills & Nash, Bruce Hornsby and Springsteen. 
Springsteen and Thompson remained friends after Steel Mill broke up, and would sometimes play together on stage when Springsteen was in the area. 
Thompson released several solo albums over the years. He also had a passion for sailing on the Chesapeake Bay.
